title: 110_hr2100
content: The "Equal Opportunity Protection and Civil Rights Restoration Act of 2007" prohibits discrimination and preferential treatment. The "Equal Opportunity Protection and Civil Rights Restoration Act of 2007" prohibits intentional discrimination or preferential treatment based on race, color, national origin, or sex in federal contracts, employment, programs, and activities. It also prohibits requiring or encouraging discrimination in connection with federal contracts, licenses, or financial assistance. The "Equal Opportunity Protection and Civil Rights Restoration Act of 2007" prohibits discrimination or preference based on race, color, national origin, or sex in federal contracts, employment, and education. Recipients of federal aid are not allowed to discriminate in contracts, employment, or admission to educational institutions. The Act allows for benefits to historically Black colleges and universities, actions related to Indian tribes under specific laws or treaties, and sex-based classifications in employment that are exempt from Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Act exempts sex-based classifications in employment from Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. It also does not affect immigration or nationality laws. Within 6 months of the Act's enactment, each federal department or agency head must review and modify existing policies to comply with the Act, reporting any changes to the House and Senate Judiciary Committees. SEC. 6. REMEDIES. Any person aggrieved by a violation of section 2 or 3 may obtain relief in a civil action against the violator, including back pay. A prevailing plaintiff shall be awarded attorney's fees. This section does not affect other available remedies. SEC. 7. EFFECT ON PENDING MATTERS. This Act does not affect pending cases or contracts/subcontracts in effect before enactment. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions are provided for terms such as "Federal Government," "preference," and "historically Black college or university."
